questions.question: They are preparing the report. / The report …………………………….. by them.
questions.description: In the present continuous tense, the passive form is made with is/are/am + being + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They took the child to hospital. / The child ………………………….. to hospital.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: She answered the question. / The question ………………………….. by her.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: She has written four novels. / Four novels ……………………………. by her.
questions.description: In the present perfect tense, the passive form is made with has/have + been + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: The chief guest gave away the prizes. / The prizes …………………………….. by the chief guest.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: The dacoit killed the traveler. / The traveler …………………………. by the dacoit.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They robbed him at gunpoint. / He …………………………… at gunpoint.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: He has won a lottery. / A lottery …………………………. by him.
They made all the furniture out of teak. / All the furniture …………………………. out of teak.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: She called me a liar. / I ……………………………… a liar.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: He sells newspapers at the railway station. / Newspapers ………………………………… by him.
questions.description: In the simple present tense, the passive form is made with is/am/are + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: He bought the painting at an auction. / The painting …………………………… at an auction.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: I …………………….. a nice hat for the picnic.
questions.description: The active verb is used when the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: The poor dog ……………………….. badly by the cruel master.
questions.description: Use a passive verb when the subject is the receiver of the action.

questions.question: At school we ………………………… science, mathematics, grammar and history.
questions.description: Either learned or were taught is here.

questions.question: Who ……………………… the cuckoo to sing so sweetly?
He ………………………… to take a break.
All of my questions ………………………….
questions.description: Use the passive verb form when the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: She …………………….. abroad for higher studies.
questions.description: The go cannot be used in the passive form.

questions.question: She ……………………….. to a correction home to learn good manners.
questions.description: Use the passive verb form when the subject is the receiver of the action.

questions.question: He ………………………… for twenty years.
The injured man ………………………… to the hospital immediately.
The stolen diamonds …………………………. by the police.
questions.description: Either have been recovered or were recovered is possible here. Both are in the passive form.

questions.question: He …………………………. of stealing the helmet.
questions.description: They accused him of stealing the helmet. / He was accused of stealing the helmet.

questions.question: The message ……………………………….. delivered.
questions.description: The passive verb form is used when the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The messenger …………………………….. the message.
questions.description: Use the active verb form when the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: They ………………………….. the parcel in the morning.
questions.description: The present perfect cannot be used with definite past time expressions.

questions.question: He ……………………………. to leave.
questions.description: The passive form is used when the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The culprit ……………………………
questions.description: Either the present perfect (passive) or simple past (passive) is possible here.

questions.question: The suspect …………………………… to the crime.
I …………………………….. the invite.
questions.description: The present perfect is used to give news.

questions.question: The invites ……………………………..
The kitten ……………………………. home yesterday.
questions.description: The present perfect cannot be used with past time expressions.

questions.question: I ……………………….. a cake for my daughter’s birthday.
questions.description: Either simple past or the present perfect is possible here.

questions.question: I …………………………. her a necklace.
She ……………………….. me some flowers.
They are cleaning the room. / The room ………………………………… by them.
I sent the parcel in the morning. The parcel ………………………………… in the morning.
They praised the girl for winning the championship. / The girl ………………………………… for winning the championship.
She congratulated him. / He ……………………………….. by her.
I know the answer. / The answer …………………………… to me.
She told me a story. / I ……………………………. a story by her.
They brought him to Kerala. / He ……………………………. to Kerala.
I have invited all of my friends to my party. / All of my friends ……………………………. to my party.
They will finish the job by evening. / The job ………………………….. by evening.
I support the plan. / The plan …………………………….. by me.
Plants absorb carbon dioxide. / Carbon dioxide …………………………… by plants.
She feeds stray dogs. / Stray dogs ................................. by her.
She was cheated by her friends. Her friends ……………………….. her.
questions.description: Was cheated is the passive form of cheated.

questions.question: The man was bitten by the dog. The dog ………………………. the man.
questions.description: Was bitten is the passive form of bit.

questions.question: She has been promoted. They …………………………….. her.
questions.description: Has been promoted is the passive form of has/have promoted.

questions.question: I was inspired by his speech. His speech …………………………. me.
questions.description: Was inspired is the passive form of inspired.

questions.question: The road is being repaired. They ………………………….. the road.
questions.description: Is being repaired is the passive form of are/is repairing.

questions.question: You will be punished for this. They ……………………………… you.
questions.description: Will be punished is the passive form of will punish.

questions.question: The flowers were being plucked by the child. The child ………………………….. the flowers.
questions.description: Were being plucked is the passive form of were/was plucking.

questions.question: He has been informed of the accident. We …………………………. him of the accident.
questions.description: Has been informed is the passive form of has/have informed.

questions.question: The suspected are being questioned by the police. The police ……………………………… the suspected.
questions.description: Are being questioned is the passive form of is/are questioning.

questions.question: Tables and chairs are made by carpenters. Carpenters ………………………. tables and chairs.
The injured were being treated by the doctors. The doctors ………………………… the injured.
The letter was posted in the morning. I …………………………… the letter in the morning.
questions.description: Was posted is the passive form of posted.

questions.question: They have been informed by us. We …………………………… them.
questions.description: The active verb in the present perfect has the form: have/have + past participle.

questions.question: The milk was drunk by the cat. The cat …………………………. the milk.
questions.description: Was drunk is the passive form of drank.

questions.question: The missing child has been found. They ………………………….. the missing child.
questions.description: Has been found is the passive form of has/have found.

questions.question: The injured were taken to hospital. They …………………………… the injured to hospital.
questions.description: Were taken is the passive form of took.

questions.question: The winners were praised by all. All people ………………………………. the winners.
questions.description: Were praised is the passive form of praised.

questions.question: The hall is being decorated. They ……………………………… the hall.
questions.description: Is being decorated is the passive form of is/are decorating.

questions.question: The man was bitten by the dog. The dog ……………………….. the man.
questions.description: Was bitten is the passive form of bit.

questions.question: A large house is owned by her. She ……………………………. a large house.
questions.description: Is owned is the passive form of own/owns.

questions.question: A laptop was bought by her. She ………………………….. a laptop.
questions.description: Was bought is the passive form of bought.

questions.question: The match will be won by us. We …………………………….. the match.
questions.description: Will be won is the passive form of will win.

questions.question: The house is being built. They ……………………………. the house.
questions.description: Is being built is the passive form of is/are building.

questions.question: It is being investigated. We …………………………………. it.
questions.description: Is being investigated is the passive form of is / are investigating.

questions.question: The Pied Piper’s music attracted the rats of Hamelin. The rats of Hamelin …………………………… by the Pied Piper’s music.
questions.description: In the simple past, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle.

questions.question: Everybody had forgotten him. He ……………………………. by everybody.
questions.description: In the past perfect, the passive form is made with had + been + past participle.

questions.question: We can see stars at night. Stars ……………………….. at night.
They have spent a lot of money on the new house. A lot of money ……………………….. on the new house.
questions.description: In the present perfect, the passive form is made with has/have + been + past participle.

questions.question: I have posted the letter. The letter …………………………. by me.
questions.description: In the present perfect, the passive form is made with has/have + been + past participle.

questions.question: We find coconut palms in many parts of the country. Coconut palms ……………………….. in many parts of the country.
questions.description: In the simple present, the passive verb form is made with is/am/are + past participle.

questions.question: Someone has stolen my collection of stamps. My collection of stamps ……………………….. by someone.
questions.description: In the present perfect, the passive form is made with has/have + been + past participle.

questions.question: Why did they give her a big box? Why …………………………….. a big box?
questions.description: In the simple past, the passive form is made with was/were + past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: We have received no information. No information ………………………….. by us.
They offered him a job. He …………………….. a job.
We will conduct the meeting tomorrow. The meeting ………………………….. tomorrow.
questions.description: In the simple future, the passive form is made with will + be + past participle.

questions.question: Will they complete it in a month? Will it …………………………. in a month?
They eat apples. Apples ………………….. by them.
questions.description: In the simple present tense, we make passive verb forms by putting is/am/are before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: I wrote a letter. A letter ………………… by me.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, we make passive verb forms by putting was/were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: He is writing a poem. A poem ……………………….. by him.
questions.description: In the present continuous, the verb has the form: is / am/are + being + past participle.

questions.question: They were repairing the roof. The roof …………………….. by them.
questions.description: In the past continuous, the verb has the form: was / were + being + past participle.

questions.question: She has bought a new car. A new car …………………….. by her.
questions.description: In the present perfect, the verb has the form: has + been + past participle.

questions.question: I had sent the parcel. The parcel ……………………….. by me.
questions.description: In the past perfect, the passive verb has the form: had + been + past participle.

questions.question: The teacher punished the child. The child …………………. by the teacher.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, we make passive verb forms by putting was/were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: I will help him. He …………………… by me.
questions.description: In the simple future, the verb has the form: will + be + past participle.

questions.question: He has sold his house. His house ………………………. by him.
questions.description: The passive verb in the present perfect has the form: has/have + been + past participle.

questions.question: They will have sent the money. The money …………………… by them.
questions.description: The passive verb in the future perfect has the form: will + have + been + past participle

questions.question: The police are investigating the crime. The crime ……………………. by the police.
questions.description: In the present continuous tense, we make passive verb forms by putting is/are/am   + being before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They rescued the child. The child …………………….. by them.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, we make passive verb forms by putting was/were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: She will not recognize us. / We ………………………… by her.
questions.description: In the simple future tense we make the passive forms by putting the past participle form of the verb after will be.

questions.question: They didn’t invite me, but I went anyway. / I ………………………… but I went anyway.
questions.description: In the simple past tense we make the passive form by putting was / were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They broke up the table for firewood. / The table ………………………. up for firewood.
questions.description: In the simple past tense we make the passive form by putting was / were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: This book will change your life. / Your life ……………………….. by this book.
questions.description: In the simple future tense we make the passive forms by putting the past participle form of the verb after will be.

questions.question: She has won the first prize. / First prize …………………………. by her.
questions.description: In the present perfect tense, we make the passive form by putting the past participle form of the verb after has/have + been.

questions.question: A friend of mine is repairing the car. / The car ……………………………. by a friend of mine.
questions.description: In the present continuous tense we make the passive form by putting is/am/are + being before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: The immigration officer questioned us. / We …………………………. by the immigration officer.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, we make the passive form by putting was/were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: They speak English in Nagaland. / English ……………………… in Nagaland.
questions.description: In the simple present tense, we make the passive form by putting is/am/are before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: His attitude shocked me. / I ……………………… by his attitude.
questions.description: In the simple past tense, we make the passive form by putting was/were before the past participle form of the verb.

questions.question: She had already sent the parcel. / The parcel ……………………………. by her.
questions.description: In the past perfect tense, we make the passive form by putting the past participle form of the verb after had been.

questions.question: They will hire some people to do the job. / Some people ………………………… to do the job.
questions.description: In the simple future tense, we make passive forms by putting the past participle form of the verb after will be.

questions.question: Her silence worries me. / I ……………………….. her silence.
Rabid dogs ………………………… by forest rangers in Maine last year.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action. Something is done to it.

questions.question: His racy lifestyle ……………………….. many women.
questions.description: We need an active verb here because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: The defeated candidate ………………………….. up and down in a rage.
questions.description: We need an active verb here because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: All those in favor should ………………………….. their hands.
questions.description: To raise is to lift something.

questions.question: We all ……………………….. when the judge entered the court.
questions.description: To rise is to get up on one’s own accord.

questions.question: We …………………………. to stroll around the neighorhood on sunny afternoons.
questions.description: We use the simple present tense to talk about likes and preferences.

questions.question: The company ……………………….. a large range of products.
questions.description: Since there is no reference to past time, we use the simple present tense here.

questions.question: Buying a boat ……………………….. low on my list of priorities.
questions.description: Here the subject is the –ing form buying. When a gerund is the subject, the verb is usually singular.

questions.question: His rapacious ways ………………………… him wealthy but friendless.
questions.description: We use the simple past tense to simply state that something happened.

questions.question: He rarely …………………………, yet he passed every exam.
questions.description: When one verb is in the past tense, the other verb will most probably also be in the past tense.

questions.question: I rate that performance one of the best I ……………………………
questions.description: The present perfect tense is more common with indefinite time expressions like ever and never.

questions.question: Each flood victim ………………………….. with a daily ration.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: This poem …………………………. by Tagore.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action. Tagore wrote this poem. When we change it into passive, we get ‘This poem was written by Tagore’.

questions.question: The matter ………………………….. tomorrow.
questions.description: They will discuss the matter tomorrow. When we change it into the passive voice, we get ‘The matter will be discussed tomorrow’. We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The government …………………………. its plans to build a bridge over the river.
questions.description: We need an active verb because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: Let the room …………………………..
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: Two battles ……………………… here a hundred years ago.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The results ……………………………… yet.
questions.description: They have not announced the results yet. When we change this into the passive voice, we get: The results have not been announced yet.

questions.question: He ………………………… to get out.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: Has the parcel …………………………?
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The tables and chairs ………………………… by the carpenter.
questions.description:
We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.
The carpenter is making the tables and chairs. When we change it into the passive voice, we get: The tables and chairs are being made by the carpenter.

questions.question: Everybody …………………………… him.
questions.description: We need an active verb because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: The scandal ……………………….. in a few days.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject is not the doer of the action.

questions.question: The boys ………………………… the window.
questions.description: We need an active verb because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: Malini ............................. a colorful hat for her daughter.
questions.description: We need an active verb here because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: The dog ............................... up in the kennel by its master.
questions.description: The dog does not perform the action here. It is the recipient and hence we need a passive verb form here.

questions.question: The winners ............................ by the principal.
questions.description: We use passive forms when the object is the doer of the action.

questions.question: Susie ............................ a chocolate cake for her sister's birthday.
questions.description: We need an active verb form here because the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: Who ......................... this book on Greek mythology?
The salesman .......................... all the questions patiently.
questions.description: The active verb in the simple past tense is the second form of the verb.

questions.question: The instructor ........................... the players to be careful.
questions.description: We use active verb forms to say who performed the action.

questions.question: She ............................. in
questions.description: The present perfect tense is not used with past time adverbs.

questions.question: The police .................................. the stolen goods.
questions.description: We use an active verb here because the subject is the doer of the action. The present perfect is used to talk about finished actions when there is no time reference.

questions.question: The patient .............................. to the intensive care unit.
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the action is not performed by the patient.

questions.question: The parents ............................. the children abroad for higher education.
questions.description: The parents perform the action here and hence we use the active verb.

questions.question: A doctor ........................... to be compassionate.
questions.description: We use the simple present tense to talk about a general truth.

questions.question: The mall ................................... by the police on the orders of the mayor.
questions.description: When we say what happens to people and things we use the passive verb forms.

questions.question: She ................................. as an expert on parenting.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms.

questions.question: This book ................................. your life.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms.

questions.question: The furniture ............................... up for firewood.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms.

questions.question: French .......................... in France and several other countries in Europe.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms.

questions.question: The roof .................................. by a friend of mine.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms. The option 'is repairing' is in the present continuous tense (active) and the option 'has repaired' is in the present perfect tense (active). Since something is being done to the roof, we need a passive verb form here.

questions.question: Small babies need to ........................................
questions.description: We need a passive verb here because the subject (small babies) is not the doer of the action. Something is being done to them.

questions.question: Too many books ................................. about the World Wars.
questions.description: When we say what people and things do, we use active verb forms. When we say what happens to people and things, we often use passive verb forms.

questions.question: Before going to bed, she ................................. her books neatly on the table.
questions.description: We use the active voice when the subject is the doer of the action.

questions.question: I have already .................................. his photo to the policeman.
questions.description: When the subject is the doer of the action, we need an active verb.

questions.question: The curator ................................ us a collection of old manuscripts.
questions.description: Both 'showed' (simple past) and 'has shown' (present perfect) are possible here. Since the subject is the doer of the action, we need an active verb here.

questions.question: The mason ..................... the wall.
The gate .....................… by the peon.
The wounded man ...................... by the boys.
The work ....................... in two weeks.
By whom ………………….?
Why was such a letter ………………… by your father?
She …………………. a check.
A thunderstorm often ………………… milk sour.
He teaches English. / English ................... by him.
The child is eating bananas. / Bananas .................... by the child.
She is writing a letter. / A letter ....................... by her.
The master punished the servant. / The servant ......................... by the master.
He was writing a book. / A book ....................... by him.
Who wrote this letter? / By whom ......................?
Somebody cooks meal every day. / Meal ...................... by someone every day.
He wore a blue shirt. / A blue shirt .................... by him.
May God bless you with happiness! / ................... with happiness.
They are building a house. / A house ...................... by them.
I have finished the job. / The job .......................... by me.
I sent the report yesterday. / The report ................... yesterday.
The horse ................................... by the syce every day.
The problem …………………. to the children.
Those pyramids …………………. around 400 AD.
All the trouble ………………… .. by your mother.
The visitors …………………. a collection of old manuscripts.
I …………………. him ten thousand pounds last year.
She ………………… of spiders.
That picture …………………. by my grandmother.
I ………………….. by his attitude.
Excuse the mess. The house …………………
I knew why I ………………….
People ......................................... to park in front of their gate.
Passengers .......................................... to book their tickets early.
I did not beat her.
answers: She is not beaten by me.
She has not beaten by me.
She was not beaten by me.

questions.question: I will never forget this experience.
answers: This experience is not forgotten by me.
This experience would never be forgotten by me.
This experience will never be forgotten by me.

questions.question: Mother made a cake yesterday.
answers: A cake made by mother yesterday.
A cake is made by mother yesterday.
A cake was made by mother yesterday.

questions.question: The boy teased the girl.
answers: The girl was teased by the boy.
The girl had teased by the boy.

questions.question: Did she do her duty?
answers: Was her duty done by her?
Had her duty done by her?

questions.question: The tiger was chasing the deer.
answers: The deer was chased by the tiger.
The deer was being chased by the tiger.
The deer had chased by the tiger.

questions.question: She has written a novel.
answers: A novel has written by her.
A novel has been written  by her.
A novel had written by her.

questions.question: She has learned her lessons.
answers: Her lessons has learned by her.
Her lessons have been learned by her.
Her lessons had been learned by her.

questions.question: Have you finished the report?
answers: Has the report finished by you?
Has the report been finished by you?
Had the report been finished by you?

questions.question: The police have caught the thief.
answers: The thief has been caught by the police.
The thief was caught by the police.
The thief had been caught by the police.

questions.question: Without effort, we ................................. gain nothing.
Let the weak and the oppressed not ................................
Wealth ....................................... by all and is acquired by some.
We ......................................... the information on our computer.
A very remarkable discovery ......................................... by him.
